p: The diagnosis of infectious diseases usually requires professional knowledge, sophisticated equipment and sufficient power sources; however, these are difficult to achieve in areas with poor economic foundations ( 92, 93). The new generation of CRISPR-based molecular diagnostic technology [such as Specific High-sensitivity Enzymatic Reporter (SHERLOCK)] ( 94, 95) do not rely on electricity as much as PCR, has lower cost, faster times and simple operation ( 94, 95). The advantages of matching the efficiency and accuracy of qPCR technology have made significant contributions to the fight against Ebola outbreaks in Nigeria, where power is often lost ( 92, 93).
